title: 114_hr4943
content: The Act may be cited as the "Tribal Tax and Investment Reform Act of 2016". The Congress recognizes the unique legal and political relationship between the United States and Indian tribes, acknowledging tribes' authority to provide governmental programs, develop economies, and maintain infrastructure on reservation lands. Federal laws and regulations affirm tribes as governments with the authority to tax, issue bonds, and receive tax exemptions. Indian tribes have the authority to tax, issue bonds, and receive tax exemptions like other governments. Codifying tax parity with tribal governments aligns with Federal treaties recognizing tribal sovereignty. Tribes face historic disadvantages in accessing capital for infrastructure and governance due to statutory restrictions. Some provisions in the Internal Revenue Code result in unfair tax treatment for tribal citizens. Congress has the authority to regulate commerce with Indian tribes to further tribal self-governance and affirm the government-to-government relationship with tribes. Indian tribes are treated as states with respect to bond issuance. Indian tribal governments are treated as states for certain purposes, including tax-exempt bonds. The Secretary of the Treasury establishes a national bond volume cap for bonds issued by Indian tribal governments based on tribal population estimates and minimum State ceiling amounts. The national bond volume cap for Indian tribal governments is determined by the Secretary of the Treasury based on tribal population estimates and minimum State ceiling amounts. A repeal of certain requirements in the Code is also made, with the amendments applying to obligations issued in calendar years after the enactment of the Act. The amendment made by subsection (a) applies to obligations issued in calendar years after the enactment of this Act, while the repeals made by subsection (b) apply to transactions and obligations issued in calendar years after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. Treatment of pension and employee benefit plans by tribal governments. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include expanding the definition of qualified public safety employee to include Indian tribes and updating the definition of governmental plan to include plans established by Indian tribal governments. The term 'governmental plan' under the Internal Revenue Code now includes plans established by Indian tribal governments, subdivisions, agencies, or entities wholly owned or controlled by them. Additionally, the definition of domestic relations order has been expanded to include tribal entities. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include tribal entities in the definition of domestic relations order and governmental deferred compensation plans. Plans established and maintained by Indian tribal governments are grandfathered under certain conditions. Plans established and maintained by Indian tribal governments are grandfathered under certain conditions, including those defined in the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include plans established by Indian tribal governments, subdivisions, agencies, or entities controlled by them. Additionally, a domestic relations order now includes tribal entities. Conforming amendments are also made to the Act. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include plans established by Indian tribal governments, subdivisions, agencies, or entities controlled by them. Conforming amendments are made to the Act, allowing for the inclusion of tribal entities in employee benefit plans. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include plans established by Indian tribal governments, subdivisions, agencies, or entities controlled by them. The amendments apply to years beginning after the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. Tribal foundations and charities treated like charities funded and controlled by governmental funders and sponsors. The amendment expands the definition of "governmental unit" to include Indian tribal governments and related entities for tax purposes. Additionally, certain supporting organizations are now deemed to include Indian tribal governments and related entities. The amendment expands the definition of "governmental unit" to include Indian tribal governments and related entities for tax purposes, with the amendments applying to taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act. Improving tribal child support enforcement agencies by granting access to federal parent locator service and tax refund offsets. Access to Federal Parent Locator Service and improving the collection of past-due child support from federal tax refunds for Indian tribes and tribal organizations eligible for grants under specific sections of the Social Security Act. The text chunk discusses the applicability of certain sections to Indian tribes and tribal organizations eligible for grants under the Social Security Act, as well as an amendment to the Internal Revenue Code to include references to Indian tribes and tribal organizations. Section 7 of the text amends the Internal Revenue Code to include Indian tribal governments for determining special needs under the adoption credit. The amendments apply to taxable years after the enactment of the Act.
